text: It was the dawn
of a new era for the British Empire.
For the first time since Spanish conquistadors
claimed La Florida 250 years earlier,
all of the Atlantic Coast of North America
was finally under the control of Great Britain.
We all know about the 13 British colonies.
But at the time of the Revolution,
there weren't 13 British colonies... there were 15.
Nobody knows that, hardly.
Spain had given up La Florida in 1763
in exchange for recovering Cuba from the British.
England created East and West Florida as royal colonies,
making them the 14th
and 15th British colonies
in North America,
that would later become part of the U.S.
East Florida stretched from the Atlantic
to the Apalachicola River.
St. Augustine,
now 300 buildings strong,
was the capital.
West Florida, with the smaller settlement of Pensacola
as the capital,
reached to the Mississippi.
East Florida and West Florida have been completely
written out of the narrative.
Search "13 British colonies"
and you will not find numbers 14 and 15.
It was a radical changing of the guard.
The scrappy melting pot of European, Native,
and black communities
that had eked out a rough frontier life under Spanish rule
had evacuated to Mexico and Cuba.
And stepping in to govern the colony of East Florida
was a British aristocrat, Colonel James Grant,
heir apparent of Ballindalloch Castle
in the Scottish Highlands.
Grant was literally of the manor born,
growing up on this 10,000acre estate in Speyside,
which has been kept in the family for centuries.
Many of the rooms remain as they were
when the castle was built in 1545.
I always think it's such a shame the walls can't talk.
'Cause think of the wonderful stories
that must be in every room.
Grant left is comfortable life here to fight for his country
when he was 24.
He was a very big military man.
He was obviously very bright.
He had a great estate.
He had lots of servants to look after him.
And he needn't have done that.
He could've stayed here on the estate and done nothing.
Grant left the lush, rolling hills of Scotland
for the relentless heat and sandy soil of East Florida,
hoping to transform this unmanageable territory
into a viable British trade colony.
The governor of West Florida was another aristocrat
who had been a commander in the Royal Navy.
Commodore George Johnstone had a reputation
for being hottempered, scheming, and duplicitous.
But he was vigorous about encouraging trade
in the new colony.
Here was a subtropical region that suddenly they had
that might potentially allow them
to grow some sort of fruits or vegetables
they would have to go elsewhere for.
They saw East Florida and West Florida
as an extension of the Caribbean.
So they saw agricultural profits.
Many of the missing pieces of the story of British Florida
were hidden in the attic turret at Ballindalloch Castle,
buried among thousands of other papers
that had been stored there and forgotten for centuries.
In the 1970s, Grant's descendants
asked the Scottish National Archives
to inventory what was there.
A decade later, Dr. Dan Schafer was allowed access to the papers

That's where the records were.
The whole James Grant letter collection
were in the castle in a far attic,
in the cold, in a room where they were stored very well,
but nobody knew they were there.
This country, I am convinced is totally unknown.
Grant's letters describe East Florida
as completely undeveloped,
still in a state of nature when he arrived.
And since only three families
remained after the Spanish left St. Augustine,
Grant had no one to help harness the wilderness beyond town.
How are you going to develop a province
when there's nobody here?
Grant began by offering free land
to successful plantation owners in other colonies.

Well, if they come in to St. Augustine

five nights out of the week.
Yeah, he was quite a party guy.

And if you were to see that,
how much alcohol passed through his cellars...
Those inventories, along with Grant's letters,

in Edinburgh.
During his first year in office,
beverages drunk from the Governor's cellars
tallied 86 gallons of Madeira wine,
76 gallons Tenerife wine,

Unusual for that captain.

but he got home sober."

Back in East Florida, illness forced Governor Grant
to return to England for medical care.
Two years later, he was elected to Parliament
and resigned as governor.
A new leader was appointed, Colonel Patrick Tonyn,
who ran into opposition almost immediately.
He was the nastiest person I've ever read a letter from.
He hated everybody.
He had a chip on his shoulder the size of Ireland.
Such a vindictive nature that he had, and so selfserving.
I find it really hard to like the man.
Tonyn drew resistance from several of Grant's friends,
including one who publicly insulted Tonyn's wife.
He announced, "I will not allow my wife and daughters
to interact with Mrs. Tonyn.
I knew her in Scotland, and she was a whore."
So the gauntlet was thrown immediately.
And Tonyn never forgot. He never forgave.
Several clashed with Tonyn over the issue of governance.
The colonists believed they had the same rights
as they had had in Britain,
such as electing representatives to a colonial house of assembly.
Tonyn viewed such demands as disloyalty to the Crown.
Former governor Grant wrote letters back to Florida
assuring his friends
that his successor would soon win them over...
but he didn't.
"You predicted that Governor Tonyn
would bring all into good humor
and drowned animosity in a bottle of claret.
You're quite mistaken in your man.
I went to one of his first parties
and he served bad food on a dirty tablecloth,"
and then continues with, "in all the comfort of a dirty whore."
Tonyn lost even more ground when he began to mistreat
the three domestic slaves he had promised to purchase from Grant.
Do you understand me?!
Alexander, who Governor Grant had trained to be a prized baker
for all these great affairs, dinners, that he was having,
was punished by putting an iron mask around his head
that padlocked in the back.
"Alexander stopped me in the street.
He complains of the iron caps.
He wishes very much to be your baker again.
He complains that madame is the devil.
But since I saw him, he has had the cap put on
and been flogged."
Alexander and the two other slaves
eventually ran away to the woods.
When Grant heard about this,
he insisted that they be given sanctuary at his own plantation.
"You are publicly to make it known that Governor Tonyn
has nothing to do with them, that they have nothing to fear."
Which is a most remarkable thing.
To rebuke the other governor publicly
was a remarkable thing to do.
But ironically, just a few years later,
Tonyn would cast himself as a great liberator,
and in doing so, he would turn people against
one of his more vocal critics.
That man was Dr. Andrew Turnbull,
who ran the largest plantation in all of North America.
Turnbull is dreaming big, big dreams, amazing dreams,
and he had no idea the troubles that lay ahead of him.
Educated at the University of Edinburgh,
Turnbull studied medicine there when he was only 13.
When the British started offering land grants in Florida,
Turnbull and his two wealthy partners
were granted over 100,000 acres.
There's nothing like that in colonial American history.
This is just massive in its scale.
Turnbull personally recruited indentured workers from Menorca,

More than 1,400 people.
"And I'm going away as fast as possible,
as the Governor has taken umbrage at my taking

I beg Sir William that you will not say any of this

after I've gotten safely away from here."
If the Turks had apprehended and jailed him,

or they would've killed him.

Everything would be paid for them.

They would be indentured laborers.

Accomplished on a huge scale
development of plantationbased economy with export products

Turnbull was influential back in England.
When he criticized East Florida's governance,

So there was a real clash between these two men.

the Turnbull venture was finished.
It was a terrible failure,
actually, because about half of his labor force died

inability to buy things.
